I have always been curious about the personal experiences that people have which convince them to believe in the supernatural - be it God, the soul, or any other supernatural idea. It has always been a touchy subject to bring up since people consider these experiences very personal and, most of the time, are unwilling to openly present them due to fear of criticism or ridicule.
 
 So, I am trying an experiment in this thread in that I am inviting people to share those experiences with the ground rules that this is intended as a survey only without any of those posts being open for discussion. So, no responses commenting on those posts are allowed - especially not negative ones. Of course, such a thing is hard to police and some people might respond to your posts anyway. However, in the ground rules of this forum, the posters need feel NO OBLIGATION to respond to such rule-breakers. These rules are set out to make people feel more comfortable presenting their experiences.
 
 -----
 To start with myself, though most unusual experiences I have had could be reasonably explained also with probability and/or psychological interpretation, there is one that to this day remains mysterious and hard to justify. Namely, when I was an early teenager, my grandmother died. She had been relatively sick for years but there was nothing to indicate that the sickness had gotten any worse or that she was near death. The afternoon of her death, after school, the thought popped into my head that she was dead and I spoke it out loud to my brother. That thought had never occurred to me before, I had not been thinking a lot about her recently and the thought was not accompanied by any strong emotion. It simply came "out of the blue". That evening, my mother came home crying since her mother, my grandmother, had died. That experience was such a very low probability and unusual occurrence that it has remained a mystery to me to this day - one that opens my intellectual curiousity to the possibility of a supernatural.
 
 So, would you be willing to share your experiences?

Religion is the only field I know of where experience is automatically discounted, simply on the basis of it being religion.

 With respect, I don't think that's true. Testimony based on personal experience is also viewed with scepticism in matters such as alien visitations, poltergeist encounters and homeopathic cures. Anywhere, in fact, where the testimony runs counter to most people's experience of how the world works. Religion is not singled out here.
 
 We all construct our own mental model of how the world works. When someone makes an extraordinary claim, whether of alien abduction or of religious revelation, we tend to test the claim against our world-view and ask which is more consistent with it - the truth of the claim, or the testimony being unreliable. Have we ever experienced alien abduction? Probably not. Have we ever experienced another individual's personal testimony that has proven to be false or mistaken? Probably. The scales are thus tilted toward scepticism, but to call that tilt prejudice is a little harsh, I think. It has not been pre-judged that all personal testimony is necessarily false, merely that extraordinary claims need extraordinary evidence; and testimony of personal experience is all too ordinary, and all too fallible.

 I myself am on-the-fence where religion is concerned. I tend to oscillate between agnosticism and some version of Christianity. I was brought up under a moderate version of Catholicism but shifted away from it both due to intellectual reasons and due to distaste of the hate-filled rhetoric of many on the religious right. As a scientist/engineer, I place a tremendous amount of trust in the scientific method. However, I acknowledge that science cannot give answers to every question. Does that mean that religion can? It tries to and often times its answers are much more emotionally sattisfying than the scientific ones. For ex., the scientific analysis shows that those such as Hitler or Stalin who committed such attrocities on a mass scale barely suffered in life, whereas most religions promote some sort of cosmic justice. There are many such areas in which religion gives the more sattisfying answer which, I think, constitutes part of its draw. At least, those aspects are the ones which draw me most to wanting to believe in some sort of supernatural. 
 
 However, I fully acknowledge that wanting to believe something is true and it being true are two entirely different things. I believe in following the evidence, but sometimes there is no evidence either way and one either assumes that the cracks in scientific knowledge cannot be filled by anything that is not present in those areas that are known by science, or one might take a leap of faith into supernatural beliefs. If there is no scientific evidence of the supernatural, then is there any other type of evidence that might support it? I agree that anecdotal evidence is very unreliable but I think it is worth hearing out - which is what I was hoping for in this thread. Some anecdotal evidence can certainly be explained away by probability or psychological interpretations. However, so many people seem to have mysterious experiences that are hard to explain away with science or logic (including my experience of my grandmother's death) that I hold out hope that perhaps there is something behind those experiences.
 
 The fact that religions vary so widely does not, in my mind, disprove them. No religion is imune to human interpretation (I am sure that you would claim that all religions are purely human interpretation and imagination). However, perhaps there is some common thread among them that constitutes a real supernatural - not just an imagined one. I think the only way to explore this is to hear people out. I would rather hear an unchallenged version of these experiences than not hear them at all. That is why I set up the ground rules of this thread.

 At the same time they seem inclined to see coincidences in things.
 as such this leads me to the belief that these are more connected to their state of mental health than anything else.

 I certainly agree that most unusual experiences can be explained by more conventional means. For example, in college, I was particularly stressed at one point and woke up in the middle of the night with the image of my paternal grandmother (not the one whose death I previously mentioned) floating above me. Though it would be nice to think otherwise, I think that experience also could have been explained by a combination of stress and the newly awoken state I was in.
 
 However, my experience (from the first post) of the death of my maternal grandmother truly remains a mystery to this day. The thought that popped into my head that she had died really came out of the blue since the sickness that she had for years had not gotten particularly worse, we had not been talking or especially thinking about her recently, and I had no way of knowing that she had died until my mother came home that evening with the news. I also never had such random thoughts pop into my head before or after (I was not prone to such random guesses). I cannot think of any logic or practically possible reason why that experience should have happened. It remains an intriguing mystery to me. I have heard enough of these types of intriguing stories that it leaves me intellectually open to the possibility of a supernatural (i.e. processes that are not currently explainable by science).
johnhanks

However, I fully acknowledge that wanting to believe something is true and it being true are two entirely different things.

 Absolutely. To think otherwise is to fall into the Appeal to Consequences fallacy.
 
The fact that religions vary so widely does not, in my mind, disprove them.

 This must necessarily be true, since disproving a claim of an entity's existence is in principle impossible. When the truth-claims of different religions clash, however, this can only serve to cast doubt on them.
 
However, perhaps there is some common thread among them that constitutes a real supernatural - not just an imagined one.

 Or perhaps the common thread tells us something about the way human brains are wired.
 
I think the only way to explore this is to hear people out. I would rather hear an unchallenged version of these experiences than not hear them at all. That is why I set up the ground rules of this thread.

 And so, belatedly, I will respect those rules and bow out.
Archangel

 I have had a number of spiritual experiences in my life. I can think of two rather profound experiances. One as a Christian and one that played a part in my conversion.
 
 1. It was late, I was alone in the dark and had been in prayer for some hours and had reached a deep meditative state. Upon contemplation of the crucifixion I cried out into the night "My God it must have been so painful, why lord did you choose to die this most terrible way" and instantly, not a few minutes after giving me time to think of an answer for myself but instantly I heard a voice, it was the lords voice and he said that he had choosen this kind of death to reveal to mankind on a human level the incomprehensable pain that he suffers when we sin. Instantly I realised that neither Jew or Roman were guilty of putting him to death but me. I understood that it was me who dragged him before the court and tried him, that it was me who condemned him before the crowds, it was me who spat in his face and lashed him half to death. It was me who nailed him to the tree and crowned him with thorns and I was doing it over and over and *over again*.
 
 Well as you can imagine I was in a terrible state a few days had passed and I had been miserable so I visited my parish priest. Bless him he tried his hardest to reassure me that now that Jesus was in heaven he no longer felt pain. He wanted me to put it out my mind that I had through my own mind made it up. So I tried to do as he had said and about a week had passed and although a little more relaxed having being reassured by my priest I still felt a little down. It was then on the Saturday afternoon while watching a Catholic TV station that a short programme came on about the lives of different saints, I wasnt paying too much attention to it, the programme that I was interested in had finished and I was thinking about that so I am not sure which saint it was they were highlighting but the saint was a female saint. She had experianced visual apparitions of our lord throughout her life and she too had asked him the same question and this is no ####...the answer was the same as what I had been given.... that is no ####, on my heart before God, that is true!
 
 However their conversation had continued where I had been somewhat emotionally incapable of keeping the meditative state she had continued to converse with the lord and he said to her....The physical pain was all worth while if just one sinning human being loved him a little more and that he would do it all *over again*
 
 I was an emotional wreck again but this time it wasnt sadness but Joy.

 It was early morning, I was in bed in an inbetween state of being awake and asleep. I was with 2 of my firends in one of my firends back garden when i heard what sounded like hymns turning I saw a man sitting on the back step to my firends house immediatly thinking it was my father I went to see what he wanted. I had gotten into the middle of the lawn when a great wind engulffed me in a swirling sensation, at first I was afraid and I tried to fight it but it was so powerful I couldnt advance. Realising that the wind was not harming me I opened my arms to experiance its power and slowly I was lifted up, i just kept going up and up, above the streets and houses until I was perched on an invisable ledge at a great hight, but not so high to be unable to see the action on earth below and I watched people going about their daily lives I saw my village and surrounding area and when I looked I saw the whole earth each home each village each city each person in great detail all at once. I noticed that around each and every person wrapped around them was a black cloak and I then felt a presence behind me and out the corner of my eye a bright white light, I knew it was the lord and I said "forgive them for the whole world is shrouded in sin" as I turned towards him. It was then that the light emmiting from him made me realise that I cast a shadow and I fell at his feet sobbing... "forgive me for I too am shrouded in sin"......Then I felt a hand upon my head and an undescribable feeling surged through my entire being, my body and my soul, It is a feeling I had never expereianced in my life before or after that event, sometimes I get a similar yet different and so infinatly less intense experieance from the sacrament of reconciliation.
